{{Use mdy dates|date=August 2012}} {{Infobox person | name = Leiby Kletzky | birth_name = Yehudah Kletzky{{cite web |url=http://www.thejewishweek.com/news/new_york/haredi_sensitivity |title=Haredi Sensitivity |last=Goldman |first=Ari L. |work=[[The Jewish Week]] |date=19 July 2011 |accessdate=20 July 2011}} | image = File:Leiby Kletzky.jpg | image_size = | other_names = | caption = | birth_date = {{Birth date|2002|07|29}} | birth_place = [[Brooklyn]], [[New York (state)|New York]] | death_date = {{Death date and age|2011|07|12|2002|07|29}} | death_place = Brooklyn, New York | death_cause = Lethal drug cocktail; smothering | known_for = Kidnap/murder victim | nationality = [[United States nationality law|American]] | home_town = Brooklyn, New York | parents = Nachman Kletzky
Itta Esther (Esti) Forster Kletzky | residence = }} On July 11, 2011, '''Leiby Kletzky''', a [[Hasidic Judaism|Hasidic]] [[Jews|Jewish]] boy, was kidnapped as he walked home from his school day camp in the mainly Hasidic neighborhood of [[Borough Park, Brooklyn|Boro Park]], [[Brooklyn]] in [[New York City]], [[New York (state)|New York]]. Kletzky's disappearance sparked an all-out search by New York City police and a block-by-block search by up to 5,000 [[Orthodox Judaism|Orthodox Jewish]] volunteers from New York and other states coordinated by the Brooklyn South [[Shomrim (volunteers)|Shomrim]] volunteer civilian patrol. His [[Dismemberment|dismembered]] body was found in the [[Kensington, Brooklyn, New York|Kensington]] apartment of Levi Aron, aged 35, and in a dumpster in another Brooklyn neighborhood, [[Greenwood Heights, Brooklyn|Greenwood Heights]], on Wednesday morning July 13. Videos from [[Closed-circuit television|surveillance cameras]] along the boy's route showed him meeting a man outside a dentist's office and then apparently getting into his car. The dentist's reception records led police to Aron at his apartment, where he showed them parts of the boy - and told them where he had dumped the rest of the body. The kidnapping and murder of the eight-year-old boy shocked the insular Brooklyn Hasidic community, whose streets are considered relatively safe. Aron gave a 450-word handwritten confession to police after his arrest, but pleaded not guilty at his first court hearing. Before the case went to trial, on August 9, 2012 Aron pleaded guilty to one charge of second-degree murder and one charge of second-degree kidnapping as part of a [[plea bargain]] agreement worked out between prosecutors and defense attorneys. On August 29, Judge Neil Firetog sentenced Aron to 40 years to life in prison. Aron would be eligible for [[parole]] in 2051, which includes credit for time served. The case drew drawn comparisons to the 1979 kidnapping of six-year-old [[Etan Patz]] from nearby [[SoHo]], who was snatched while walking to his school bus for the first time.{{cite web |url=http://cityroom.blogs.nytimes.com/2011/07/14/a-new-horror-recalls-another/ |title=A New Horror Recalls Another |last=Haberman |first=Clyde |date=14 July 2011 |work=[[The New York Times]] |accessdate=16 July 2011}} ==Disappearance== Yehudah Kletzky, known as "Leiby", was the third of six children and only son of Nachman Kletzky and Esti Forster Kletzky, [[Boyan (Hasidic dynasty)|Boyaner]] Hasidim and residents of Boro Park."Leiby Kletzky, z"l". ''[[Hamodia]]'' American News, 21 July 2011, p. B26.{{cite web|url=http://www.jewishpress.com/pageroute.do/49093 |title=Leiby Kletzky (2002–2011) |last=Tannenbaum |first=Rabbi Gershon |work=[[The Jewish Press]] |date=20 July 2011 |accessdate=21 July 2011 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20110812062551/https://www.jewishpress.com/pageroute.do/49093 |archivedate=August 12, 2011 |df= }} He was reported missing late Monday afternoon while walking home from a day camp held at his school, Yeshiva Boyan Tiferes [[Mordechai Shlomo Friedman|Mordechai Shlomo]].{{cite web |url=https://www.nytimes.com/2011/07/14/nyregion/borough-park-residents-reeling-with-news-of-boys-death.html?_r=1&scp=4&sq=leiby%20kletzky&st=cse |title=After Coming Together for a Frantic Search, a Community Is Left Reeling |work=The New York Times |last=Robbins |first=Liz |date=13 July 2011 |accessdate=14 July 2011}}{{cite web |url=http://www.latimes.com/news/nationworld/nation/la-naw-boy-in-refrigerator-20110713,0,3090581.story |title=Boy's remains found in refrigerator; New York man in custody |author=Associated Press |date=13 July 2011 |publisher=[[Los Angeles Times]] |accessdate=14 July 2011}} Kletzky had begged his parents to let him walk home from the camp instead of taking the school bus. It was the first time that his parents allowed him to walk alone and they had practiced the route the day before; his mother waited for him at a predetermined point a few blocks away at 50th Street and 13th Avenue. The boy missed a turn upon leaving camp and headed in the wrong direction.{{cite web |url=https://www.wsj.com/articles/SB10001424052702304911104576444400698099640?mod=googlenews_wsj |title=Case Prompts Parents to Ask: How Old Is Old Enough? |date=14 July 2011 |last=Reddi |first=Sumathi |accessdate=14 July 2011 |work=The Wall Street Journal}} ===Search=== Kletzky's mother called the Brooklyn South Shomrim volunteer civilian patrol to report a missing child at 6:14 p.m. Brooklyn South Shomrim, which says it receives 10 calls of missing children per day,{{cite web |url=http://cityroom.blogs.nytimes.com/2011/07/15/in-hasidic-areas-first-call-for-help-isnt-to-911/?scp=8&sq=kletzky%20video&st=cse |title=For Hasidim, First Call for Help Often Isn't to 911 |date=15 July 2011 |accessdate=17 July 2011 |work=The New York Times |last=Kilgannon |first=Corey}} immediately checked candy stores, other shops, and homes of friends and relatives where the boy might have gone. By 8:30 p.m., Shomrim contacted the New York City Police Department, which declared a Level 1 search, something normally undertaken after a child is missing for 24 hours. The police search involved [[Search and rescue dog|canine units]], [[mounted police]], and [[Police aviation|helicopters]]. On Tuesday morning, Brooklyn South Shomrim, together with Shomrim organizations in [[Crown Heights, Brooklyn]], [[Flatbush, Brooklyn|Flatbush]], and [[Williamsburg, Brooklyn|Williamsburg]] made an all-out call for volunteers to join the search. Five thousand Orthodox Jewish volunteers from the local community and from as far away as [[New York metropolitan area|the tri-state area]], joined in a block-by-block search.{{cite web |url=http://blogs.villagevoice.com/runninscared/leibykletzkymissingposter.jpg |title=Missing Child Alert |publisher=New York Police Department |accessdate=14 July 2011 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20120928104847/http://blogs.villagevoice.com/runninscared/leibykletzkymissingposter.jpg# |archive-date=September 28, 2012 |dead-url=yes |df=mdy-all }}{{cite web |url=http://newyork.cbslocal.com/2011/07/17/a-look-inside-brooklyns-shomrim-patrol/ |title=A Look Inside Brooklyn's Shomrim Patrol|date=17 July 2011 |accessdate=18 July 2011 |publisher=CBS New York}} [[Bangladeshi diaspora|Bangladeshi]] residents of nearby Kensington also joined the search.{{cite web |url=http://articles.nydailynews.com/2012-02-09/news/31043450_1_bangladeshis-anti-muslim-graffiti-allah |title=Anti Muslim graffiti insulting Allah scrawled on Kensington insurance shop |first=Simone |last=Weichselbaum |work=[[New York Daily News]] |date=9 February 2012 |accessdate=3 March 2012}} [[New York State Assembly|State Assemblyman]] [[Dov Hikind]] posted a $5,000 reward for information leading to the return of the child, which was eventually upped to $100,000 by members of the community. Meanwhile, Yaakov German, a [[Bobov (Hasidic dynasty)|Bobover]] Hasid and father of Kletzky's yeshiva rebbi, went door-to-door on Tuesday morning with his son to examine videos from surveillance cameras posted in stores and offices along the boy's route. The videos showed that after leaving his school at 1205 44th Street, between 12th and 13th Avenues, at about 5:05 p.m., Kletzky missed his turn at 13th Avenue and continued down 44th Street.{{cite web |url=http://www.nydailynews.com/news/ny_crime/2011/07/15/2011-07-15_i_just_cant_stand_to_see_something_like_this_happening_in_our_community_how_his_.html |title=Amateur sleuth Yaakov German helps cops catch Levi Aron and solve murder of Leiby Kletzky |work=New York Daily News |date=15 July 2011 |accessdate=17 July 2011 |last=Paddock |first=Barry}} Other videos showed the boy walking by Shomrim Locksmith at 44th Street and 15th Avenue, and then along 44th Street at 17th Avenue. On 18th Avenue, the boy was seen talking to a man who then crossed the street and entered a dentist's office. When the man came out, Kletzky followed him and appeared to get into his car. After examining the videos, police located the dentist, who alerted his receptionist, the wife of community political operative [[Simcha Eichenstein]].Shaer, Matthew (December 4, 2011) [https://www.nymag.com/news/features/levi-aron-2011-12/index4.html "A Monster Among the 'Frum'"], ''New York Magazine''. "[Simcha] Eichenstein’s wife, Herbst knew, worked for Sorscher as a receptionist. Elbowing Bernstein out of the way, Herbst uploaded a clip of the bearded man and sent it to Eichenstein. Eichenstein sent it to his wife, at home with her small children. “Of course,” she told her husband. She couldn’t remember the man’s name, but she was sure she had seen him. “He came in to pay a bill. He was the last one in the office." She gave them the name and address of the suspect who had come in to pay his bill that day. After midnight on Tuesday, police also managed to identify the car in the surveillance video as a 1990 gold Honda Accord.{{cite web |url=http://www.irishcentral.com/news/Irish-American-cop-cracked-murder-of-8-year-old-Brooklyn-boy-Leiby-Kletzky-126055488.html |title=Irish American cop cracked murder of 8-year-old Brooklyn boy Leiby Kletzky |last=Hayes |first=Cathy |work=Irish Central|date=23 July 2011 |accessdate=23 July 2011}} Forty-five minutes later, two Flatbush volunteers searching for the missing boy in Kensington spotted the car and sent in the license-plate number, which matched Aron's details. Police went to the suspect's apartment in Kensington around 2 a.m. Wednesday morning. They arrived to an open door, and when they asked Aron where the boy was, he allegedly nodded toward the kitchen, where the police found blood-soaked carving knives and bloody towels in bags.{{cite web |url=http://www.theyeshivaworld.com/news/General+News/97357/NYPD%3A-Leiby-Kletzky-Had-Gotten-Lost-%26-Asked-Suspect-For-Help.html |title=NYPD: Leiby Kletzky Had Gotten Lost & Asked Suspect For Help |date=13 July 2011 |accessdate=13 July 2011 |work=[[Yeshiva World News]]}} The boy's severed feet were found in the freezer.{{cite web |title=Brooklyn, NY – NYPD: Man Implicated Self; No Relation To Family |work=Vosizneias |url=http://www.vosizneias.com/87349 |date=13 July 2011 |accessdate=13 July 2011}} The suspect told police where to find the rest of the remains: in a red suitcase{{cite web |url=http://blogs.villagevoice.com/runninscared/2011/07/leiby_kletzkys.php |title=8-year-old Brooklyn boy is killed and dismembered; Orthodox Jewish neighborhood is shocked |author=Associated Press |date=13 July 2011 |accessdate=14 July 2011 |publisher=[[The Washington Post]]}} thrown in a dumpster on 20th Street between [[Fourth Avenue (Brooklyn)|Fourth]] and [[Fifth Avenue (Brooklyn)|Fifth]] Avenues.{{cite web |url=http://cityroom.blogs.nytimes.com/2011/07/13/boys-body-found-suspect-being-questioned/ |title=Missing Boy's Dismembered Body Found; Suspect Says He Panicked |date=13 July 2011 |accessdate=13 July 2011 |work=The New York Times |last1=Baker |first1=Al |last2=Robbins |first2=Liz |last3=Goldstein |first3=Joseph}} Aron was taken into police custody at 2:40 a.m. Wednesday morning. ===Confession=== According to a 450-word handwritten statement in which he confessed to killing the boy, Aron claimed that Kletzky had asked him for directions and accepted a ride, saying he wanted to be dropped off at a bookstore. Aron suggested that they drive together to a wedding in [[Monsey, New York]]; they returned around 11:20 p.m. Aron claimed that he planned to return the boy to his family on Tuesday, but when he saw the missing child posters the next day, he said he "panicked", returned to the apartment, and smothered the boy with a towel. Then he dismembered the body and stuffed it into bags, which he placed in a suitcase and left in a dumpster in another neighborhood.{{cite web |url=http://www.cbsnews.com/stories/2011/07/14/national/main20079404.shtml |title=NYC boy spent hours with suspect before murder |date=14 July 2011 |accessdate=14 July 2011 |publisher=CBS News}} A video from the security camera at the Ateres Charna wedding hall in [[Rockland County, New York|Rockland County]] confirmed that Aron was at the wedding, but no sign is seen of Kletzky.{{cite web |url=https://www.wsj.com/articles/SB10001424052702304521304576446433004865952 |title=Suspect Recounts Time With Child |last1=Gardiner |first1=Sean |last2=Hollander |first2=Sophia |date=15 July 2011 |accessdate=1 August 2011 |work=The Wall Street Journal}} A color surveillance video taken later that night at a [[Sunoco]] gas station on the [[Palisades Interstate Parkway]] showed Aron and Kletzky getting out of Aron's car and going into the bathroom. The video was time-stamped 8:15 p.m.{{cite web |url=http://matzav.com/the-palisades-gas-station-attendant-who-saw-leiby |title=The Palisades Gas Station Attendant Who Saw Leiby |date=21 July 2011 |accessdate=1 August 2011 |publisher=matzav.com}} There was no evidence that the victim had been sexually abused. Aron was unknown to Kletzky before meeting the boy on the street. Child abductions by strangers are extremely rare in New York State, with none of the 20,000 children who went missing in 2010 having been taken by a stranger, according to state statistics.{{cite web |url=http://online.wsj.com./article/SB10001424052702304911104576444431957206902.html?mod=googlenews_wsj |title=Missing Brooklyn Boy Found Dead: 8-Year-Old Was Victim of 'Totally Random' Abduction |first1=Sean |last1=Gardiner |first2=Eileen |last2=Markey |first3=Andrew |last3=Grossman |work=The Wall Street Journal |date=13 July 2011 |accessdate=14 July 2011}} ===Funeral=== Kletzky's funeral, held on Wednesday in the parking lot of a [[Borough Park, Brooklyn|Boro Park]] [[synagogue]] was attended by thousands of Orthodox Jews, many of whom traveled from throughout the [[Tri-State area (NY-NJ-CT)|Tri-State area]] to attend.{{cite web |url=http://www.nydailynews.com/blogs/dailypolitics/2011/07/thousands-mourn-brooklyns-leiby-kletzky-8 |title=Thousands Mourn Brooklyn's Leiby Kletzky, 8 |last=Katz |first=Celeste |date=14 July 2011 |accessdate=14 July 2011 |work=New York Daily News}} Attendance was estimated at 8,000 by the Shomrim civilian patrol, and 10,000 by [[Arutz Sheva]].{{cite web |url=http://www.israelnationalnews.com/News/News.aspx/145702 |title=10,000 Attend Funeral of 9-Yr-Old Leiby Kletzky in Boro Park |last=Sidman |first=Fern |date=14 July 2011 |accessdate=14 July 2011 |publisher=[[Arutz Sheva]]}} ==Perpetrator== Levi Aron is an Orthodox Jew who grew up in Brooklyn. His father, Jack, works at the Hasidic-owned B&H Photo in Brooklyn; his mother, Basya, died five or six years previously. Aron lived in the attic apartment of his parents' three-family home on the corner of Avenue C and East 2nd Street in the Kensington neighborhood. He was married twice; in 2004 he married Diana Diunov, an Israeli woman, and in 2007 he married Deborah M. Parnell of [[Tennessee]], a divorced mother of two whom he had met online and with whom he moved to [[Memphis, Tennessee|Memphis]], where he worked as a security guard. Both marriages ended in divorce.{{cite web |url=https://www.nytimes.com/2011/07/15/nyregion/suspect-pleads-not-guilty-in-leiby-kletzkys-death-and-offers-account.html?pagewanted=2&_r=1&ref=nyregion |title=Police Sort Through Suspect's Account as He Pleads Not Guilty in Killing |last1=Barron |first1=James |last2=Baker |first2=Al |work=The New York Times |date=14 July 2011 |accessdate=18 July 2011}} Aron worked as a clerk at a hardware-supply company in Brooklyn. He was described by his coworkers as quiet and socially awkward.{{cite web |url=http://newyork.cbslocal.com/2011/07/13/co-workers-suspect-in-leiby-kletzky-murder-acted-normal-during-investigation/ |title=Acquaintances: Suspect In Leiby Kletzky Murder Showed No Warning Signs |date=13 July 2011 |accessdate=15 July 2011 |publisher=CBS New York}} Aron had injured his head when he was hit by a car while riding his bike at the age of 9 and suffered problems stemming from that accident. It is believed that this caused extreme shyness and neurotic behaviors with Aron in later life. He had no prior arrest record. He had been served with an Order of Protection in January 2007 and had received a fine for a seat belt violation and one speeding ticket. In Brooklyn, authorities cited a summons for public urination.{{cite web |url=http://www.israelnationalnews.com/News/News.aspx/145716 |title=Who is Levi Aron, Accused Killer of Leiby Kletzky? |date=14 July 2011 |last=Ya'ar |first=Chana |publisher=Arutz Sheva |accessdate=14 July 2011}} ==Legal proceedings== ===Defense attorneys' statements=== Aron appeared in Brooklyn Criminal Court on July 14, 2011, and pleaded not guilty. At the hearing, his lawyer stated that Aron "suffers from hallucinations" and "hears voices". The court ordered Aron to be sent to the prison ward at [[Bellevue Hospital Center]] for a [[Psychological evaluation|psychiatric evaluation]].{{cite web |url=http://www.thejewishweek.com/news/breaking_news/kletzky_murder_suspect_bellevue_psychiatric_tests |title=Kletzky Murder Suspect In Bellevue For Psychiatric Tests |last=Magnus |first=Cynthia |date=15 July 2011 |accessdate=17 July 2011 |work=Jewish Week}} After Aron had been hospitalized, his lawyers stated that he was "seeking to quiet the voices in his head by listening to music". They also described his demeanor as "abnormal".{{cite web |url=http://www.nbcnewyork.com/news/local/125761373.html |title=Accused Killer Quiets Voices in Head With Music, Lawyers Say |first1=Jonathan |last1=Dienst |first2=Shimon |last2=Prokupecz |date=18 July 2011 |accessdate=18 July 2011 |publisher=[[NBC]]}} In December 2011, another of Aron's attorneys, Howard Greenberg, sparked outrage when he remarked of his client, "Look, everybody knows when blood relations have offspring, there can be genetic defects... There's inbreeding in that community" – the latter referring to the Hasidic Jewish community of New York City.{{cite web |url=http://www.nypost.com/p/news/local/brooklyn/inbred_outrage_94xSKANEEIE5BmhY4Z1rCJ|title='Inbred' Outrage |first=Jose|last=Martinez|work=New York Post|date=22 December 2011|accessdate=7 September 2013}} ===Autopsy findings=== On July 20, 2011, the [[Office of Chief Medical Examiner of the City of New York|office of the New York City medical examiner]] released autopsy results revealing that Kletzky had ingested a lethal mix of four different drugs and had then been [[Asphyxia#Smothering|smothered]]. The cause of death was determined to be intoxication from a combination of [[cyclobenzaprine]] (a [[muscle relaxant]]), [[quetiapine]] (an [[antipsychotic]]), and [[hydrocodone]] and [[Paracetamol|acetaminophen]] (two [[analgesic]]s), followed by smothering. Upon release of the autopsy results, the case was officially ruled a [[homicide]].{{cite web |url=https://www.forbes.com/feeds/ap/2011/07/20/general-us-missing-boy_8575270.html |title=Kidnapped NYC boy was given drugs, then smothered |author=Associated Press |publisher=[[Forbes]] |date=20 July 2011 |accessdate=20 July 2011}} On August 9, 2011, the New York City medical examiner's office revealed that Kletzky had ingested a fifth drug, [[Duloxetine]], which is used for [[generalized anxiety disorder]] and as an [[antidepressant]]. The blood tests revealing this drug took a few weeks to process at an outside lab.{{cite web |url=http://www.theyeshivaworld.com/news/General+News/99555/EXCLUSIVE%3A-Blood-Tests-Reveal-5th-Drug-Was-Given-To-Leiby-Kletzy-Before-Being-Killed.html |title=EXCLUSIVE: Blood Tests Reveal 5th Drug Was Given To Leiby Kletzy Before Being Killed |date=9 August 2011 |accessdate=18 August 2011 |work=Yeshiva World News}} ===Indictment=== Hours after the autopsy results were released on July 20, a Brooklyn [[grand jury]] indicted Aron on eight counts of murder and kidnapping – including two counts of [[Murder (United States law)#Degrees of murder in the United States|first-degree murder]], three counts of second-degree murder, two counts of first-degree kidnapping, and one count of second-degree kidnapping{{cite web |url=http://www.ny1.com/content/top_stories/143295/leiby-kletzky-s-accused-killer-indicted-on-felony-murder-charges/ |title=Leiby Kletzky's Accused Killer Indicted on Felony Murder Charges |last=Anderson |first=Tetiana |work=NY1 |date=July 20, 2011 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20121004191855/http://www.ny1.com/content/top_stories/143295/leiby-kletzky-s-accused-killer-indicted-on-felony-murder-charges/ |archivedate=October 4, 2012 |df=mdy-all }} – which carries a maximum sentence of life in prison without parole.{{cite web |url=https://www.nytimes.com/2011/07/21/nyregion/leiby-kletzky-was-drugged-before-being-suffocated-official-says.html |title=Brooklyn 8-Year-Old Was Drugged, Then Suffocated, Medical Examiner Says |last1=Berger |first1=Joseph |last2=Baker |first2=Al |date=July 20, 2011 |work=The New York Times}} A day after the indictment was handed down, one of Aron's lawyers, Gerard Marrone, resigned from the case, saying that he could not represent the defendant as "the allegations were too horrific". Attorney Jennifer McCann joined Pierre Bazile for the defense.{{cite web |url=https://www.wsj.com/articles/SB10001424053111903461104576462632375189412 |title=Defense Shifts in Kletzky Murder |date=23 July 2011 |accessdate=23 July 2011 |last=Gardiner |first=Sean |work=The Wall Street Journal}}{{cite web |url=http://abclocal.go.com/wabc/story?section=news/local/new_york&id=8262876 |title=Attorneys of suspect in Leiby Kletzky murder quits |date=22 July 2011 |accessdate=24 July 2011 |publisher=WABC}} The case was prosecuted by the Kings County (Brooklyn) District Attorney's Office. The lead prosecutor was veteran Assistant District Attorney Julie B. Rendelman of the Homicide Bureau. Ms. Rendelman was the attorney who successfully prosecuted Horace Moore for the stabbing murder of NYC bus driver Edwin Thomas.{{cite web |url=http://newyork.cbslocal.com/2010/10/07/man-found-guilty-in-bus-drivers-stabbing-death/ |title=News Man Found Guilty In Bus Driver's Stabbing Death|date=7 October 2010 |accessdate=24 July 2013 |publisher=WCBS}} Also assigned to the case was Assistant District Attorney Linda Weinman. ===Arraignment=== Aron was declared competent to stand trial in an [[arraignment]] at the New York State Supreme Court in Brooklyn on August 4, 2011.{{cite web |url=http://cityroom.blogs.nytimes.com/2011/08/04/levi-aron-ruled-competent-for-trial-in-leiby-kletzky-murder/ |title=Levi Aron Called Fit for Trial in Leiby Kletzky Murder |last=Robbins |first=Liz |work=The New York Times |date=4 August 2011 |accessdate=7 August 2011}} Results of the psychiatric evaluation, obtained by [[Associated Press]], indicate that Aron was diagnosed with an [[adjustment disorder]]. The suspect was said to be "confused and apathetic", with a "'practically blank' personality".{{cite web |url=http://www.macon.com/2011/08/10/1661250/ap-exclusive-child-slaying-suspect.html |title=AP Exclusive: Child-slaying suspect has disorder |last=Long |first=Colleen |date=10 August 2011 |accessdate=12 August 2011 |work=[[Associated Press]] }}{{dead link|date=February 2018 |bot=InternetArchiveBot |fix-attempted=yes }} In addition, the psychologist [[Apperception|apperceived]] him as reserved, apathetic, sad and cooperative, and diagnosed a [[schizoid personality disorder]].{{cite web|title=Brooklyn slaying suspect has "schizoid" disorder|url=http://www.cbsnews.com/news/brooklyn-slaying-suspect-has-schizoid-disorder/|work=CBS News|accessdate=10 August 2011}}{{cite book|title=Crime Classification Manual: A Standard System for Investigating and Classifying Violent Crime|date=2013|isbn=1118419847|page=https://www.google.com/search?q=isbn%3A1118419847+Levi+Aron&btnG=Search&tbo=p&tbm=bks|url=https://books.google.com/books?isbn=1118419847}}{{cite web|last=Coscarelli|first=Joe|title=Levi Aron Has a Personality Disorder|url=http://nymag.com/daily/intelligencer/2011/08/levi_aron_has_a_personality_di.html|work=NY Mag|accessdate=11 August 2011}} Details also emerged that Aron had a younger sister who died while institutionalized for [[schizophrenia]].{{cite web |url=https://www.google.com/hostednews/ap/article/ALeqM5jnPmDC0_98GUdk_dnwBo0KX3tRKQ?docId=28fdbe63dd9045dc862c3467f3bcbbe4 |title=Clarification: Dismembered Boy story |author=Associated Press |date=11 August 2011 |accessdate=12 August 2011}} Aron was held at [[Rikers Island]] on round-the-clock [[suicide watch]]. He gave his first media interview to the ''[[New York Post]]'' on August 12, 2011. He did not refer to Kletzky by name, and kept referring to the smothering and dismembering of the boy as "the incident". He did not explain why he took and kept the boy, saying, "He looked familiar. I thought I knew him".{{cite web |url=http://www.nydailynews.com/ny_local/2011/08/12/2011-08-12_butcher_talks_li_panicked_sez_killer_who_wont_apologize_licalls_leibys_brutal_sl.html |title=Leiby Kletzky killer Levi Aron won't apologize for brutal slaughter, calls murder 'the incident' |last=Blau |first=Reuven |date=12 August 2011 |accessdate=12 August 2011 |work=[[New York Post]]}} On August 23, 2011, the State Supreme Court justice assigned to the case, Justice Neil J. Firetog, chided Aron's lawyers in court for discussing the case on their [[Facebook]] pages, accused them of leaking the court-ordered psychological examination to the press, and questioned their ability to handle such a complex case given their lack of experience. Pierre Bazile, who passed the bar in 2007, had defended only one homicide case, while Jennifer McCann had defended six cases, three of them ending in acquittal.{{cite web |url=https://www.nytimes.com/2011/08/24/nyregion/judge-criticizes-levi-arons-defense-lawyers.html |title=Lawyers Defending Suspect in Boy's Death Are Scolded |last=Robbins |first=Liz |work=The New York Times |date=23 August 2011 |accessdate=28 August 2011}}{{cite web |url=https://www.washingtonpost.com/national/judge-questions-experience-of-defense-lawyers-in-nyc-case-of-dismembered-boy/2011/08/24/gIQA6hm8aJ_story.html |title=Judge questions experience of defense lawyers in NYC case of dismembered boy |author=Associated Press |date=24 August 2011 |publisher=[[The Washington Post]] |accessdate=28 August 2011}} A veteran criminal defense lawyer, Howard Greenberg, subsequently joined the defense team [[pro bono]] to offset the judge's criticism of lack of experience.{{cite web |url=http://cityroom.blogs.nytimes.com/2011/10/24/veteran-lawyer-joins-defense-team-for-trial-in-killing-of-brooklyn-boy/ |last=Robbins |first=Liz |title=Veteran Lawyer Joins Defense Team in Leiby Kletzky Case |date=24 October 2011 |accessdate=24 October 2011 |work=The New York Times}} ===Pre-trial hearing=== On October 24, 2011, Aron appeared at a brief hearing in the State Supreme Court via video conferencing. Outside the courtroom, his lawyers claimed that police forced Aron to write his 450-word confession, stating that he was not sane enough to be aware of his actions. They also told reporters that they were pursuing an [[insanity defense]].{{cite web |url=http://www.huffingtonpost.com/2011/10/24/levi-arons-confession-in-_n_1028673.html |title=Levi Aron's Confession In Leiby Kletzky's Killing Was Coerced: Lawyers |last=Long |first=Colleen |date=24 October 2011 |accessdate=24 October 2011 |work=[[Huffington Post]]}}{{cite web |url=https://www.reuters.com/article/2011/10/24/us-crime-boy-idUSTRE79N7R420111024 |title=Brooklyn man accused of butchering boy to plead insanity |last=Allen |first=Jonathan |date=24 October 2011 |accessdate=24 October 2011 |publisher=[[Reuters]]}} ===Denial of change of venue=== In November 2011, the Appellate Division of the State Supreme Court denied Aron's counsel's request to move the trial to [[Suffolk County, New York|Suffolk County]] or [[The Bronx]] in light of unfavorable media coverage in Brooklyn.{{cite web |url=http://www.jta.org/news/article/2011/11/08/3090181/levi-aron-to-be-tried-in-brooklyn |title=Trial of Leiby Kletzky's accused killer staying in Brooklyn |date=8 November 2011 |accessdate=13 November 2011 |work=Forward |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20111113050218/http://www.jta.org/news/article/2011/11/08/3090181/levi-aron-to-be-tried-in-brooklyn |archivedate=November 13, 2011 |df=mdy-all }} However, it reserved the right to allow the defense to re-apply for a [[change of venue]] after the jury pool was questioned.{{cite web |url=http://www.nypost.com/p/news/local/brooklyn/klyn_man_who_allegedly_killed_boy_kNvQFF77diidBl1kcKXzwI |title=B'klyn man who allegedly killed boy will face trial in borough |last=Gorta |first=William J. |work=New York Post |date=7 November 2011 |accessdate=13 November 2011}} In March 2012 Aron appeared in court via video conferencing while his attorneys scheduled a new trial date.{{cite web | url=https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=wdEf9VjVEb4 | title=Murder Suspect Levi Aron Back In Court | work=News 12 Brooklyn | date=March 13, 2012 | accessdate=July 3, 2012}} In May 2012 he appeared before the court again via videoconferencing; the video showed that he had gained at least {{convert|50|lb}} since his arrest.{{cite web |url=http://www.nypost.com/p/news/local/brooklyn/klyn_butcher_gains_at_least_pounds_jjSmc6AO0tegrFDcy2UF4L |title='B'klyn Butcher' gains at least 50 pounds at Rikers |first=Jose |last=Martinez |date=25 May 2012 |accessdate=3 July 2012 |work=New York Post}} ===Plea bargain agreement=== On August 1, 2012, it was reported that prosecutors had struck a deal with the defense in which Aron would plead guilty in exchange for a sentence of at least 40 years to life in prison.{{cite web | url=https://www.nytimes.com/2012/08/02/nyregion/levi-aron-expected-to-plead-guilty-to-killing-leiby-kletzky.html | title=Guilty Plea Is Expected in the Killing of Brooklyn Boy, 8 |first=Mosi |last=Secret| work=The New York Times | date=August 1, 2012 |accessdate=4 August 2012}} The Kletzky family supported this decision, wanting to avoid reliving the murder if the case went to trial.{{cite web |url=https://blogs.wsj.com/metropolis/2012/08/09/brooklyn-man-sentenced-to-in-boys-murder/ |title=Brooklyn Man Pleads Guilty in Boy's Murder |first=Pervais |last=Shallwani |date=August 9, 2012 |accessdate=August 9, 2012 |work=The Wall Street Journal}} On August 9, 2012, Aron changed his plea to guilty of one charge of second-degree murder and one charge of second-degree kidnapping at Brooklyn Supreme Court.{{cite web |url=https://www.nytimes.com/2012/08/30/nyregion/levi-aron-is-sentenced-to-40-years-in-killing-of-leiby-kletzky-8.html |title=Man Who Killed and Dismembered a Lost Boy, 8, Gets 40 Years to Life|first=C.J. |last=Hughes |date=29 August 2012 |accessdate=2 September 2012 |work=The New York Times}} He answered a series of questions from the judge in which he admitted to killing Leiby Kletzky.{{cite web |url=http://abclocal.go.com/wabc/story?section=news/local/new_york&id=8767192 |title=Levi Aron Pleads Guilty in Leiby Kletzky Murder |date=August 9, 2012 |accessdate=August 9, 2012 |work=ABC News}} On August 29, 2012, Judge Neil Firetog sentenced Aron to 25 years to life on the second-degree murder charge and 15 years to life on the second-degree kidnapping charge.{{cite web |url=http://www.nypost.com/p/news/local/brooklyn/leiby_monster_put_away_B0fTdbXKL3RvWFtVpXv35K |title=Levi Aron sentenced to 40 years to life for murder of Orthodox Jewish boy Leiby Kletzky |first1=Josh |last1=Saul |first2=Antonio |last2=Antenucci |first3=Leonard |last3=Greene|work=New York Post |date=30 August 2012 |accessdate=3 September 2012}} Aron would be eligible for [[parole]] in 2051, which includes credit for time served.{{cite web |url=https://blogs.wsj.com/metropolis/2012/08/29/brooklyn-man-sentenced-to-40-years-in-boys-killing/ |title=Brooklyn Man Sentenced to 40 Years in Boy's Killing |first1=Pervaiz |last1=Shallwani |first2=Tania |last2=Karas |work=[[The Wall Street Journal]] |date=29 August 2012 |accessdate=29 August 2012}} ===Civil lawsuits=== On August 17, 2011, Nachman Kletzky filed a $100 million civil lawsuit against Aron in Brooklyn Supreme Court, seeking damages for the "abduction, kidnapping, torture, murder and dismemberment" of his son. On August 23, Kletzky filed a $100 million civil suit against Aron's father, Jack, for neglecting to monitor his son or protect Leiby while the latter was in his home.{{cite web |url=https://www.wsj.com/articles/SB10001424053111904332804576538933681883412?mod=googlenews_wsj |title=Victim's Parents Sue Alleged Killer |work=The Wall Street Journal |date=August 30, 2011 |accessdate=August 30, 2011 |last=Shallwani |first=Pervaiz}}{{cite web |url=http://cityroom.blogs.nytimes.com/2011/08/29/slain-boys-father-sues-accused-killer-and-his-father/ |last=Robbins |first=Liz |work=The New York Times |date= August 29, 2011 |accessdate=August 30, 2011 |title=Slain Boy's Father Sues Accused Killer and His Father}} ==Proposed legislation== {{Anchor|Leiby's Initiative}}In the wake of the murder, State Assemblymen [[Dov Hikind]] and [[Peter Abbate]] and [[New York State Senate|State Senator]] [[Diane Savino]] said they would introduce a bill called "Leiby's Initiative", which would grant a $500 annual [[tax credit]] to any [[New York City]] property owner who installs and maintains surveillance cameras on their property.{{cite web |url=http://newyork.cbslocal.com/2011/07/15/lawmakers-propose-tax-credit-for-surveillance-camera-installation-after-brooklyn-tragedy/ |title='Leiby's Initiative': Lawmakers To Propose $500 Tax Credit For Surveillance Camera Installation |publisher=CBS New York |date=July 15, 2011 |accessdate=July 17, 2011}} {{Anchor|Leiby's Law}}New York City Councilman [[David G. Greenfield|David Greenfield]] has said he would propose "Leiby's Law," a bill under which businesses could volunteer to be designated as safe places for children who are lost or otherwise in trouble. Employees would undergo background checks and business owners would put a green sticker in their store windows so children know it is a safe place to get help.{{cite web |url=http://www.nydailynews.com/news/ny_crime/2011/07/21/2011-07-21_leibys_law_would_provide_safe_places_for_children_who_are_lost_or_in_trouble.html |title='Leiby's Law' would provide safe places for children who are lost or in trouble |publisher=NY Daily News |date=July 21, 2011 |accessdate=July 21, 2011}} On August 16, 2011, the Brooklyn District Attorney's office announced a similar program called "Safe Stop". So far, 76 stores have signed up to display a green "Safe Haven" sticker in their windows to help lost children.{{cite web |url=http://www.nydailynews.com/ny_local/brooklyn/2011/08/17/2011-08-17_safe_haven_for_kids_storeowners_to_post_signs_on_windows.html |title=Storeowners post 'Safe Stop' signs on windows to help lost kids |last=Rizzo |first=Lillian |date= August 17, 2011 |accessdate= August 18, 2011 |work=New York Daily News}} {{Anchor|The Leiby Kletzky Security Initiative}}In September 2013, Assemblyman Dov Hikind and [[Majority Leader of the New York State Senate|State Senate Majority Leader]] [[Dean Skelos]] announced the implementation of the Leiby Kletzky Security Initiative, which will provide the installation of 100 security cameras on public lampposts throughout the [[Midwood, Brooklyn|Midwood]] and Borough Park neighborhoods. Paid for by a $1 million state grant, the cameras will be maintained by Secure Watch 24, a private security firm and [[Limited liability company|LLC]] controlled by [[Agudath Israel of America]]. Recorded data from the cameras will be retained for up to five years.{{cite web |url=http://www.bigstory.ap.org/article/nyc-neighborhood-dismembered-boy-get-cameras |title=NYC Neighborhood of Dismembered Boy to Get Cameras |last=Pearson |first=Jake |date= September 22, 2013 |accessdate= September 22, 2013 |work=Associated Press}} According to Agudath Israel of America, camera footage will be accessed only by the New York City Police Department.{{cite web |url=http://www.vosizneias.com/152146/2014/01/13/new-york-agudah-says-only-nypd-will-be-able-to-access-leiby-security-cameras/|title=New York - Agudah Says Only NYPD Will Be Able To Access Leiby Security Cameras|first=Sandy|last=Eller|date=14 January 2014|accessdate=14 January 2014|work=[[Vosizneias]]}} =={{Anchor|Memorials}}Memorials and legacy== {{Anchor|Leiby Kletzky Memorial Fund}}On July 20, 2011, relatives of Kletzky launched a website for the newly established Leiby Kletzky Memorial Fund, which aims to raise $1 million to help children and families in crisis and need.{{cite web |url=http://www.nydailynews.com/ny_local/2011/07/21/2011-07-21_leiby_kletzkys_family_starts_website_in_honor_of_slain_boy_aims_to_raise_1_milli.html|title=Leiby Kletzky's family starts website in honor of slain boy, aims to raise $1 million for needy kids |work=New York Daily News |date=21 July 2011 |accessdate=21 July 2011|last1=Yaniv |first1=Oren |last2=Schapiro |first2=Rich |last3=Lauinger |first3=John}} In its first day of operation, the website garnered $61,581 from 1,365 donors.{{cite web |url=http://www.huffingtonpost.com/2011/07/21/leiby-kletzky-memorial-fund_n_905931.html |title=Leiby Kletzky Memorial Fund Raises $60k in One Day |author=Associated Press |publisher=[[Huffington Post]] |date=21 July 2011 |accessdate=21 July 2011}} {{anchor|"Leiby Forever" song}}In early August, Hasidic singer [[Lipa Schmeltzer]] released a ballad called "Leiby Forever" and a seven-minute music video showing home movies of Kletzky growing up. After the beginning of the video, a [[CCTV]] footage of the abduction plays.{{cite web |url=http://www.nydailynews.com/news/ny_crime/2011/08/15/2011-08-15_dad_lauds_memorial_song_about_slain_leiby.html |title='Leiby Forever' song helped me cope with son's death, Nachman Kletzky says |last=Weichselbaum |first=Simone |date=15 August 2011 |accessdate=16 August 2011 |work=New York Daily News}} In June 2017, Levi Aron's brother, Tzvi, was found dead in the same house where Leiby Kletzky's body was discovered.http://abc7ny.com/news/sources-brother-of-leiby-kletzkys-killer-found-dead-in-brooklyn-home/2063373/ ==See also== * [[List of kidnappings]] * [[List of murdered American children]] * [[Murder of Vicki Lynne Hoskinson]] ==References== {{Reflist|30em}} ==External links== * [https://www.nytimes.com/interactive/2011/08/04/nyregion/20110805-levi-aron-confession.html?ref=leibykletzky Levi Aron Confession in Leiby Kletzky Killing] * [https://web.archive.org/web/20110731040355/http://www.give2gether.com/projects/help-support-leiby-kletzky/ Leiby Kletzky Memorial Fund] * [http://www.chabad.org/library/article_cdo/aid/1575637/jewish/Statement-by-Rabbi-Nachman-and-Itta-Kletzky.htm Public statement by Rabbi Nachman and Itta Kletzky] * [http://nymag.com/news/features/levi-aron-2011-12/ "A Monster Among the 'Frum': The faithful of Borough Park have a saying: 'We are all of one face.' The life of Levi Aron, the outcast awaiting trial for the murder of 8-year-old Leiby Kletzky, suggests otherwise"] December 2011 feature in ''[[New York (magazine)|New York magazine]]'' {{DEFAULTSORT:Kletzky, Leiby}} [[Category:2002 births]] [[Category:2010s missing person cases]] [[Category:2011 deaths]] [[Category:2011 in New York (state)]] [[Category:2011 murders in the United States]] [[Category:Borough Park, Brooklyn]] [[Category:Child abduction in the United States]] [[Category:Crimes in Brooklyn]] [[Category:Deaths by person in the United States]] [[Category:Formerly missing people found dead]] [[Category:Jews and Judaism in Brooklyn]] [[Category:July 2011 events]] [[Category:Kidnapped American children]] [[Category:Missing person cases in New York]] [[Category:Murdered American children]] [[Category:Murdered American Jews]] [[Category:People murdered in New York City]]

page.title: Non-fatal offences against the person in English law

revision.text:
{{Good article}} '''Non-fatal offences against the person''', under [[English law]], are generally taken to mean offences which take the form of an attack directed at another person, that do not result in the death of any person. Such offences where death occurs are considered [[Homicide in English law|homicide]], whilst [[Sexual offences in the United Kingdom|sexual offences]] are generally considered separately, since they differ substantially from other offences against the person in theoretical basis and composition. Non-fatal offences against the person mainly derive from the [[Offences against the Person Act 1861]], although no definition of assault or battery is given there.
[[Offences against the person]] include minor forms of [[battery (crime)|battery]] (any unlawful touching of another person); its complimentary offence, [[assault]] (causing the apprehension of a battery, even when one has not yet occurred); and various more serious offences which are based on assault and battery (together called "common assault"). This includes [[assault occasioning actual bodily harm]], where the victim suffers injuries such as bruising or skin abrasions (the converse being an injury that is "transient and trifling"); wounding (a piercing of all layers of the skin); and causing grievous bodily harm (injuries more serious than in actual bodily harm, for example broken bones). The latter two offences may be committed "with intent", meaning there is an additional ''[[mens rea]]'' component that makes the defendant more culpable for their actions. Whilst [[recklessness (law)|recklessness]] is sufficient for most offences against the person – that the defendant foresaw the risk of the proscribed injury occurring without necessarily intending it to happen – this is insufficient for crimes of intent.
==General characteristics== [[File:Non-fatal offences against the person graph.png|thumb|right|250px|Number of recorded crimes (2009–10). Categories approximate non-fatal offences against the person.]] Common to all crimes against the person is the infringement of the right to [[bodily integrity]]. It extends to the touching of clothing, for example, and where no [[harm principle|physical harm]] actually results. However, if all touchings were criminalised, this would interfere with the [[right to liberty]].<ref name="simester425">Simester et al. (2010). p. 425.</ref> It is the very touching, and not the harm, that is the violation of principle. This is related to the [[right to privacy]] under Article 8 of the [[European Convention on Human Rights]].<ref name="simester425"/> The central statute on this topic is [[Offences against the Person Act 1861]], which brought together a multitude of difference offences, with much overlap and inconsistent terminology. These include both the actual infliction and the threat of violence. Although criticised, the Act has not been replaced.<ref name="simester425"/>
In the context of the [[inchoate offences in English law|law of attempts]], the [[Crown Prosecution Service]] advises that "where the evidence demonstrates that the suspect intended to cause an injury that is substantially more serious than that (if any) which was in fact caused, prosecutors should consider the circumstances of the case as a whole as well as the relevant sentencing guideline to determine the appropriate charge." <ref>{{Cite web |url=http://www.cps.gov.uk/legal/l_to_o/offences_against_the_person/ |title=Offences Against The Person |accessdate=5 July 2013 |publisher=Crown Prosecution Service}}</ref>
==Assault and battery== A distinction is drawn between the offence of [[assault]] and that of [[battery (crime)|battery]]. Assault is the ''apprehension'' of the possibility of immediate unlawful violence, and battery that of the ''infliction'' of such violence. Several proposals, including one from the [[Criminal Law Revision Committee]] in 1980 have proposed merging the offences. However, the distinction was confirmed in ''[[DPP v Little]]''<ref group="c">[1992] QB 645 (DC)</ref> in 1992. There, the [[conflation]] of assault and battery was criticised as [[Duplicity (law)|duplicitous]].<ref>Simester et al. (2010). p. 426.</ref><ref name="smith412">Smith (2002). p. 412.</ref> If D throws a punch at V, who dodges, this is likely to be an assault but not a battery; if V is attacked from behind, this may constitute a battery without an assault.<ref>Simester et al. (2010). pp. 426–427.</ref><ref name="smith413">Smith (2002). p. 413.</ref> Actions which constitute ordinary daily life are not considered assault or battery, for example, jostling on a crowded train.<ref name="simester428">Simester et al. (2010). p. 428.</ref> The term "common assault" is used to refer to either a technical assault or a battery.<ref name="smith412"/><ref name="cpscharging">{{cite web |url=http://www.cps.gov.uk/legal/l_to_o/offences_against_the_person/#P92_3540 |title=Offences against the Person, incorporating the Charging Standard |publisher=[[Crown Prosecution Service]] |year=2009 |accessdate=16 November 2011}}</ref>
===Assault=== {{main|Common assault}} Assault is a [[summary offence]] in England and Wales, with the case heard only at a [[Magistrates' Court (England and Wales)|Magistrates' Court]].<ref name="cpscharging"/><ref name="smith415">Smith (2002). p. 415.</ref> Although ''R v Little'' considered assault a statutory offence, none of the statutes referred to contain any definition of assault.<ref name="smith413"/> The ''[[actus reus]]'', endorsed in ''[[R v Ireland]]'',<ref name="ireland" group="c">[1998] AC 147</ref> is any act by D that causes V to apprehend immediate and unlawful personal violence.<ref>Simester et al. (2010). pp. 427–428.</ref> The term "force" rather than "violence" is used by the [[Crown Prosecution Service]] (CPS).<ref name="cpscharging"/> As a definition, this has proven stable, but its interpretation has varied.<ref name="simester428"/> The force must be unlawful – outside the realm of [[Self-defence in English law|defensive]] or preventative force, for example. Consent of the victim may be enough to prevent the commission of a crime. There is to debate as to whether lack of consent is an element of the ''actus reus'', making it inherent to the commission of a crime, or whether consent is a defence. [[Andrew Simester]] and [[Bob Sullivan (legal writer)|Bob Sullivan]] argue that the former is more correct, since lack on consent is vital to the crime; since the act may not constitute a harm even if enacted. The disregard for the victim's [[autonomy]] and privacy is the actionable part of the offence.<ref name="simester428"/> The victim need not be frightened by the apprehension of violence, merely not want the person concerned to do it.<ref name="simester429">Simester et al. (2010). p. 429.</ref>
Assault requires a positive act, not an [[omission (criminal law)|omission]]. Mere lawful presence in a location is not enough to satisfy the conduct requirement; illegal [[trespass to land|trespass]], however, is sufficient.<ref name="simester429"/> [[John Cyril Smith]] has suggested that wilfully refusing to retract an inadvertent act that causes the victim to apprehend violence may constitute an assault by omission.<ref name="smith415"/> It is arguable that there was once a rule that "mere words" could not constitute an assault, but the case of ''R v Ireland'' confirmed that even silent phone calls would be grounds for the charge of assault.<ref>Simester et al. (2010). pp. 429–430.</ref><ref name="elliott139">Elliott, Quinn (2006). p. 139.</ref> ''[[R. v Constanza]]'' added threatening letters to this category.<ref name="elliott139"/><ref name="simester430">Simester et al. (2010). p. 430.</ref>
Although assault involves a threat of an immediate battery, the perpetrator need not actually intend to carry out that battery.<ref name="smith414"/> It is enough that he, intentionally or recklessly, caused the victim to apprehend such an occurrence.<ref name="simester430"/> The term "immediate" has also been used in different ways. Following ''Ireland'', it seems likely that even where the victim knew the defendant was some distance away, this may be sufficient.<ref>Elliott, Quinn (2006). p. 141.</ref> As [[Lord Steyn]] said there, "what, if not the possibility of imminent personal violence, was the victim terrified about?".<ref>Simester et al. (2010). pp. 430–431.</ref> This would widen the crime of assault considerably. It is perfectly conceivable that the victim was fearful, but did not believe an attack was imminent.<ref>Simester et al. (2010). p. 431.</ref> That she actually apprehended "immediate violence", rather than merely "immediately apprehended", is doubtful.<ref name="smith414">Smith (2002). p. 414.</ref> In ''Constanza'', it was sufficient for the prosecution to show that the victim feared an attack in the future, which may have been imminent. It also suggested that the anticipated harm could be psychological rather than physical.<ref name="elliott142">Elliott, Quinn (2006). p. 142.</ref>
''[[Blake v Barnard]]''<ref group="c">(1840) 9 C & P 626; 173 [[English Reports|ER]] 985</ref> established a rule that conditional threats could not amount to an assault. However, the court's reliance on ''[[Tuberville v Savage]]''<ref group="c">(1669) 1 Mod Rep 3; 86 ER 684</ref> was tenuous at best. Such threats would normally be considered assault.<ref>Simester et al. (2010). pp. 431–432.</ref>
The ''mens rea'' requirement is that the defendant must have intend to, or recklessly, cause the victim to fear the possibility of immediate unlawful violence.<ref name="simester432">Simester et al. (2010). p. 432.</ref> There is no authority that suggests that "intend" or "recklessly" ought to mean something from their normal meanings. ''[[Recklessness (law)|Cunningham recklessness]]'' – that the defendant himself foresaw the risk of harm – is applied.<ref name="elliott142"/><ref name="simester432"/> Assault is a crime of "basic intent" for the purposes of the [[Majewski test]] concerning [[Voluntary intoxication in English law|voluntary intoxication]].<ref name="simester432"/>
===Battery=== The defendant commits a [[Battery (crime)|battery]] if they intentionally or recklessly apply unlawful force to another, without their consent.<ref name="cpscharging"/><ref name="simester432"/> It is subject to the same "everyday life" exception common to assault.<ref name="simester432"/><ref name="smith416">Smith (2002). p. 416.</ref> Cases have included kissing,<ref group="c">Dungey (1864) 4 F&F 99, 102; 176 ER 487</ref> spitting<ref group="c">Smith (1866) F&F 1066; 176 ER 910</ref> and cutting someone's hair without their consent.<ref group="c">Smith [2006] EWHC 94 (admin)</ref><ref>Simester et al. (2010). pp. 432–433.</ref> This also includes contact with the victim's clothing,<ref name="simester433">Simester et al. (2010). p. 433.</ref> a rule dating back to 1845 in ''[[R v Day]]''. It is not necessary that the victim feels the touching.<ref name="smith416"/>
The required [[causation (law)|causation]] may be quite oblique. As well as weaponry held in the hand, weaponry thrown is included, as is causing people to touch each other by creating a sense of panic.<ref group="c">Martin (1881) 8 QBD 54 (CCR)</ref><ref name="simester433"/> The general law on [[Omissions in English criminal law|liability for omissions]] also applies to batteries, for example those of the continuing act (as in ''[[Fagan v Metropolitan Police Commissioner|Fagan v MPC]]'') and of a [[duty of care]].<ref name="simester433"/> However, in ''R v Ireland''<ref name="ireland" group="c"/> the court ruled out psychological injury by means of a telephone as a form of battery, although it was not an important point in the case as other charges were brought.<ref name="simester433"/><ref name="smith417">Smith (2002). p. 417.</ref> Poisoning is not a battery where there is no accompanying violence.<ref name="smith417"/>
The case of ''[[R v Brown]]''<ref group="c">[1994] 1 AC 212</ref> established a further requirement: hostility. This is not easily called an ''actus reus'' nor ''mens rea'' requirement. It was not clear what role it played in that case, but could apply to other cases as a way of clarifying the "everyday behaviour" guidance.<ref>Simester et al. (2010). p. 434.</ref> It has been strongly criticised by [[Lord Goff]] and other judicial and academic writers. It could apply to future cases where the bodily harm was unintended or unforeseen.<ref name="simester435">Simester et al. (2010). p. 435.</ref>
The ''mens rea'' requirement for battery is similar to assault. It is the intention to apply unlawful force to another, or be reckless as to whether such force is applied.<ref>Smith (2002). p. 418.</ref> It employs ''[[Recklessness (law)|Cunningham recklessness]]'' – that the defendant must have foreseen the risk of the infliction of unlawful force upon V.<ref name="simester435"/><ref>Smith (2002). pp. 418–419.</ref> In theory, at least, combining the ''mens rea'' of battery with the ''actus reus'' of assault, or vice versa, is not a crime.<ref name="smith419">Smith (2002). p. 419.</ref> The [[Majewski test]] is applied to cases of voluntary intoxication, as battery is also a crime of "basic intent" in this scenario.<ref name="simester435"/><ref name="smith419"/>
==Assault occasioning actual bodily harm== [[Assault occasioning actual bodily harm]] carries a maximum sentence of 5 years under section 47 of the Offences against the Person Act 1861.<ref name="simester435"/><ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.legislation.gov.uk/ukpga/Vict/24-25/100/section/47 |title=Offences Against the Person Act 1861: Section 47 |work=legislation.gov.uk |accessdate=13 November 2011}}</ref> It is [[triable either way]].<ref name="cpscharging"/><ref name="smith436">Smith (2002). p. 436.</ref> Both assault (fear of violence) and battery (infliction of violence) are included,<ref name="simester436">Simester et al. (2010). p. 436.</ref> although it is possible to consider section 47 as creating two offences – one involving an assault, and one a battery.<ref name="smith436"/> "Occasioning" is generally taken to mean "causing" although [[John Gardner (lawyer)|John Gardner]] has argued that it is wider than that.<ref name="simester436"/> In discussing causation, 'frightened' people are not expected to act entirely rationally; instead, a relevant test is that of ''[[R v Roberts]]''.<ref group="c">56 Cr App R 95 (CA)</ref> There, any conduct of the victim short of "daft" could be considered caused by the defendant's actions.<ref name="simester436"/> Only the seriousness of the injury separates an assault from an assault occasioning actual bodily harm.<ref name="cpscharging"/>
The concept of "actual bodily harm" is wide. Almost all injuries are included – for example, [[bruising]] or [[Abrasion (medical)|skin abrasion]]s. Injuries are not included if they are "transient or trifling",<ref group="c">Donovan [1934] 2 KB 498 CCA</ref><ref name="cpscharging"/> but this did not cover even momentary unconsciousness.<ref group="c">T v DPP [2003] EWHC 266 (admin)</ref><ref name="simester436"/> The wide range of injuries give prosecutors considerable discretion about which charge to bring against a defendant.<ref name="simester436"/> Psychological injury is included,<ref name="smith437">Smith (2002). p. 437.</ref> so long as it forms a recognised medical condition.<ref name="simester436437">Simester et al. (2010). pp. 436–437.</ref> Mere fright or anxiety is insufficient for actual bodily harm.<ref name="smith437"/> It is limited only by the need for an actual assault or battery to have taken place.<ref name="simester436437"/>
There is no separate ''mens rea'' element from the assault or battery, making this a crime of [[constructive liability]].<ref name="smith436"/><ref name="simester437">Simester et al. (2010). p. 437.</ref> This has been defended by John Gardner, a proponent of the [[moral threshold]] theory.<ref name="simester437"/> However, this is opposed by Simester and Sullivan.<ref>Simester et al. (2010). pp. 437–438.</ref>
==Maliciously wounds or inflicts grievous bodily harm== {{main|Grievous bodily harm}} Section 20 of the Offences against the Person Act 1861 criminalises "whosoever shall unlawfully and maliciously wound or inflict any grievous bodily harm upon any other person, either with or without any weapon or instrument".<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.legislation.gov.uk/ukpga/Vict/24-25/100/section/20 |title=Offences Against the Person Act 1861: Section 20 |work=legislation.gov.uk |accessdate=13 November 2011}}</ref> The maximum penalty, five years, is the same as that for actual bodily harm, but a section 20 offence is considered more serious by the courts and the [[Crown Prosecution Service]].<ref name="simester438">Simester et al. (2010). p. 438.</ref> A judge is free on the facts of the case to allow a jury find a defendant guilty of assault occasioning actual bodily harm where a defendant is charged with a section 20 offence.<ref name="smith438">Smith (2002). p. 438.</ref>
The ''actus reus'' is the wound or infliction of grievous bodily harm (GBH). A "wound" is something that breaks all layers of the [[skin]], and must have an external component – [[internal bleeding]], however serious, is not a wound.<ref name="simster438439">Simester et al. (2010). pp. 438–439.</ref><ref name="smith439">Smith (2002). p. 439.</ref> Serious wounds would also fall under grievous bodily harm, but some qualifying wounds (a pin prick, for example) are very minor.<ref name="simster438439"/> Some wounds would therefore not qualify as grievous bodily harm.<ref name="smith439"/>
The phrase "really serious harm" was used to describe grievous bodily harm in ''R v Metheram''.<ref group="c">[1961] 3 [[All England Law Reports|All ER]] 200</ref><ref name="simester438"/> The case of ''R v Grundy''<ref group="c">[1977] Crim LR 543</ref> confirmed that injuries should be taken in their totality; that many small injuries may form a serious harm.<ref name="simster438439"/> ''R v Bollom''<ref group="c">[2004] 2 Cr App R 50</ref> confirmed the ''Grundy'' approach, and also showed that grievous bodily harm against a child was likely to require less bodily harm than that against an adult. ''[[R v Burstow]]''<ref group="c">[1998] AC 147</ref> extended "bodily harm" to include psychological trauma if it formed a recognised serious mental condition. Simester ''et al'' said that this could have wide-reaching consequences, but it is unlikely to be taken to include commonplace occurrences (relationship breakups, verbal cruelty, broken promises) – in ''Burstow'', the conduct included a prolonged and intense campaign of harassment.<ref>Simester et al. (2010). p. 439.</ref>
For a long time, ''[[R v Clarence]]'' was taken as an authority on the meaning of "inflict", which the court took to mean "an assault or battery of which a wound or grievous bodily harm is the manifest immediate and obvious result".<ref group="c">(1888) 22 QBD 23</ref> This narrow definition was extended in ''R v Martin''<ref group="c">(1881) 8 QBD 54</ref> and ''R v Halliday''<ref group="c">[1886–90] All ER 1028</ref> to include, for example, injuries sustained during an attempt of the victim to flee.<ref>Simester et al. (2010). p. 440.</ref> An injury is said to be "inflicted" if it is the result of an impact or percussion set in motion by the defendant; the injury must relate directly to the impact or percussion, but the impact or percussion may be an indirect effect of the defendant's actions.<ref name="simester441">Simester et al. (2010). p. 441.</ref> ''R v Burstow'' established that "inflict" was a near synonym of cause: in [[David Hope, Baron Hope of Craighead|Lord Hope]]'s view, they were synonymous, except that the outcome of the former must be unpleasant.<ref name="smith441">Smith (2002). p. 441.</ref> This was applied in ''[[R v Dica]]''<ref group="c">[2004] QB 1257</ref> and ''[[R v Konzani]]'',<ref group="c">[2005] EWCA Crim 706</ref> two cases of [[Criminal transmission of HIV|knowingly risking passing on HIV]] without explicit consent.<ref name="simester441"/>
The ''mens rea'' element is that of "malice", which means either intention or recklessness.<ref>Simester et al. (2010). pp. 441–442.</ref> ''Cunningham recklessness'' is applied.<ref group="c">Savage [1992] 1 AC 699</ref><ref name="smith441"/> However, for the purposes of recklessness, foresight of even minor harm is sufficient – it does not require foresight of serious harm.<ref name="smith441"/><ref name="simester442">Simester et al. (2010). p. 442.</ref> This has been criticised since it breaks the correspondence principle, that the ''mens rea'' should match the ''actus reus'' of an offence.<ref name="simester442"/>
==Wounding or causing grievous bodily harm with intent== The crime of [[Grievous bodily harm#Section 18|wounding with intent]] is created by section 18 of the Offences against the Person Act 1861. It reads, since amended, as: "Whosoever shall unlawfully and maliciously by any means whatsoever wound or cause any grievous bodily harm to any person... with intent... to do some... grievous bodily harm to any person, or with intent to resist or prevent the lawful apprehension or detainer of any person...".<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.legislation.gov.uk/ukpga/Vict/24-25/100/section/18 |title=Offences Against the Person Act 1861: Section 18 |work=legislation.gov.uk |accessdate=14 November 2011}}</ref> This creates four forms of the offence: unlawfully and maliciously wounding, with intent to either do grievous bodily harm (1) or resist arrest (2); and unlawfully and maliciously causing grievous bodily harm, with intent to either do grievous bodily harm (3) or resist arrest (4).<ref name="simester442"/> Thus forms (1) and (3) differ from section 20 offences mainly in that there is a specific intention to cause serious harm rather than some harm, and they are therefore the more serious charges. On an [[indictment]] under section 18, the jury is open to convict under section 20 or section 47 if properly directed.<ref name="smith438"/>
"Wounding" and "causing grievous bodily harm" are defined in the same way as they are in the crime of maliciously wounding or inflicting grievous bodily harm. Grievous bodily harm includes serious psychological trauma and serious infection; however, these are less controversial here because of the inclusion of intent.<ref>Simester et al. (2010). pp. 442–443.</ref> Intent narrows the crime considerably, and the term "inflict" is not used.<ref name="simester443">Simester et al. (2010). p. 443.</ref> In form (3), intent can be simply decided in the case of a direct attack, or "virtual certainty", with knowledge of the virtual certainty – the ''[[R v Woollin|Woollin]]''<ref group="c">Woollin [1999] AC 82 (HL)</ref> principle.<ref name="simester443"/><ref>Smith (2002). p. 443.</ref> In form (1), where an injury does not amount to grievous bodily harm, intent to cause grievous bodily harm (in the advancement of a different cause) must be shown. Practically, the "virtual certainty" clause cannot come into force, since grievous bodily harm was not actually caused, by definition.<ref name="simester443"/> In forms (2) and (4), the concept of "malice" has a role to play that it does not in (1) and (3). The defendant must foresee the risk of wounding or grievous bodily harm, where the core intent is to resist arrest. The defendant cannot be reckless to the resisting of arrest, it must be an intention.<ref>Simester et al. (2010). pp. 443–444.</ref> Concerning the requirement to resist a ''lawful'' arrest, the defendant only lacks the required ''mens rea'' if he believes in facts which, if true, would make the arrest unlawful; not just that he believes the facts as they are make the arrest illegal – a [[mistake of fact]] suffices, a [[mistake of law]] does not.<ref>Simester et al. (2010). p. 444.</ref>
==Other offences and issues== There also exist alternative forms of aggravated assault in English law, for example: assault or battery with intent to resist arrest (as above, the arrest must be lawful); and assault on, resistance to, and obstruction of [[constable]]s.<ref>Smith (2002). pp. 426–436.</ref> Under the [[Crime and Disorder Act 1998]], it is also possible to commit a racially aggravated assault. This is where the commission of the assault in combination to hostility towards the victim, based on their race or believed race, or association with a race. "Race" includes skin colour, nationality, citizenship, and ethnic or national origins.<ref name="smith437"/> Administering poison, either contrary to section 23 or 24 of the Offences against the Person Act 1861, is also an offence; as is false imprisonment – including unlawful arrest, kidnap and hostage situations.<ref>Smith (2002). pp. 443–457.</ref> Legislation aimed at the possession or use of firearms may also come into this category, as may [[bomb hoax]]es.<ref>Smith (2002). pp.457–465.</ref>
There are also offences of aggravated assault, created under the Offences against the Person Act 1861, that now go almost completely unused: for example, assaulting or obstructing a clergyman in the discharge of his duties, and assaulting a [[magistrate]] or other person in the exercise of his duties concerning the preservation of a vessel in distress or a wreck.<ref>Smith (2002). p. 426.</ref>
An assault is not caused if a defendant threatens to shoot the victim, but the victim is aware that the gun is not loaded or fake. However, it would be the ''actus reus'' of an assault if the victim wrongly believes the gun is, or may be, loaded. Since assault is a summary offence, no prosecutions take place for [[attempted assault]]. However, it is possible to commit attempts of aggravated forms of assault.<ref name="smith415"/>

[[File:Osterby Man.jpg|thumb|Osterby Man]] '''Osterby Man''' or the '''Osterby Head''' ({{lang-da|Østerbymanden}}) is a [[bog body]] of which only the skull and hair survive. It was discovered in 1948 by [[peat]] cutters to the southeast of [[Osterby, Rendsburg-Eckernförde|Osterby]], Germany. The hair is tied in a [[Suebian knot]]. The head is at the State Archaeological Museum at [[Gottorf Castle]] in [[Schleswig, Schleswig-Holstein]].
==Find circumstances== The head was discovered on 26 May 1948 by Otto and Max Müller of Osterby, who were cutting peat on their father's land, at {{coord|54|26|51|N|09|46|09|E}}.<ref>[[Karl Kersten]], "Ein Moorleichenfund von Osterby bei Eckernförde", ''Offa. Berichte und Mitteilungen zur Urgeschichte, Frühgeschichte und Mittelalterarchäologie'' 8 (1949) 1–2, p. 1, Fig. 1 {{de icon}}</ref> It was found approximately {{convert|65|to|70|cm|ftin}} beneath the current ground level. The head was wrapped in fragments of a deerskin cape, which Max Müller noticed protruding from the peat. The find was reported to the museum in Schleswig; despite intensive searching by the brothers and others, no more of the body has been found.<ref>[[Peter Glob|P. V. Glob]], tr. [[Rupert Bruce-Mitford]], ''[[The Bog People|The Bog People: Iron-Age Man Preserved]]'', 1971, repr. New York: New York Review Books, 2004, {{ISBN|9781590170908}}, [https://books.google.com/books?id=5e0tkA6gGT8C&pg=PA116&dq=Osterby+Man&hl=en&sa=X&ei=5Jt5UrGcN8iWiAKzg4CYDQ&ved=0CD0Q6AEwAw#v=onepage&q=Osterby%20Man&f=false p. 116].</ref>
==Description and analysis== The skull was wrapped in fragments of a deerskin cape and had been damaged by striking with a blunt object before being sunk in the bog.
===Anthropology=== The skull had been broken into several pieces. The acids in the bog have decalcified the bone, which has shrunk somewhat and is dark brown. The hair and small sections of scalp are well preserved,<ref>James M. Deem, ''Bodies from the Bog'', Boston: Houghton Mifflin, 1998, {{ISBN|9780395857847}}, [https://books.google.com/books?id=DppwAMTs5skC&pg=PT9&lpg=PT9&dq=osterby+head&source=bl&ots=A6t3sS8G1F&sig=62P8wsbSoXag0qEhe8-AAhIcXRQ&hl=en&ei=PuPlSeK3BtPonQfL7sCyCQ&sa=X&oi=book_result&ct=result&resnum=7#PPT9,M1 n.p.]</ref> but the skin and other soft tissues of the face have disappeared. There is a large wound on the left side of the head, which may have been fatal: the skull had been depressed by a blow with a blunt object over an area approximately {{convert|12|cm|in}} in diameter, and the bone of the left temple was shattered with splinters penetrating the brain area.<ref name=Eternity159>[[Wijnand van der Sanden]], tr. Susan J. Mellor, ''Through Nature to Eternity: The Bog Bodies of Northwest Europe'', Amsterdam: Batavian Lion, 1996, {{ISBN|9789067074186}}, p. 159.</ref><ref>[https://www.pbs.org/wgbh/nova/bog/iron-09.html Osterby Man, A.D. 1-100, Found near Osterby, Germany in 1948], "The Perfect Corpse: Bog Bodies of the Iron Age", ''[[Nova (TV series)|Nova]]'', retrieved 5 November 2013.</ref> The skull had also been deformed by the weight of the peat above it, but the facial area was generally well preserved. Skeletal evidence suggests a man 50 to 60 years of age. Hack marks on the second [[cervical vertebra]] show that the head was cut off.<ref name=Eternity159/> The skull was stabilised for exhibition by filling with [[gypsum]].
The hair is thin and slightly wavy, {{convert|28|cm|in}} long. It has been coloured a reddish brown by the acids in the bog; microscopic analysis showed that it had been dark blond and that the man had had some white hairs.<ref>Glob, [https://books.google.com/books?id=5e0tkA6gGT8C&pg=PA116&dq=Osterby+Man&hl=en&sa=X&ei=5Jt5UrGcN8iWiAKzg4CYDQ&ved=0CD0Q6AEwAw#v=onepage&q=originally%20been%20a%20blond%20colour%2C%20not%20particularly%20light&f=false p. 117].</ref> In a re-examination in 2005, [[Isotope analysis|isotopic analysis]] showed that at least during his last year of life, the man ate meat remarkably rarely, and did not eat seafood. [[Parasitology|Parasitological]] analysis of the hair showed no [[head lice]], unusual for the time.<ref>Heather Catherine Gill-Robinson, ''The Iron Age bog bodies of the Archaeologisches Landesmuseum, Schloss Gottorf, Schleswig, Germany'', PhD Dissertation, University of Manitoba, 2005, Ottawa: Library and Archives Canada, [2006], {{ISBN|9780494122594}}.</ref> [[File:Osterby Man Suebian-Knot.jpg|thumb|Side view showing Suebian knot]]
===Hairstyle=== The hair is unusually well preserved and is tied above the right temple in a [[Suebian knot]]. [[Tacitus]] describes this in Chapter 38 of his ''[[Germania (book)|Germania]]'' as a characteristic of free men among the Germanic tribe of [[Suebi]].<ref>[[Malcolm Todd]], ''The Early Germans'', 1992, repr. Hoboken, New Jersey: Wiley, 2009, {{ISBN|9781405137560}}, [https://books.google.com/books?id=p5QdmV3zNpIC&pg=PA112&dq=Osterby+Man&hl=en&sa=X&ei=5Jt5UrGcN8iWiAKzg4CYDQ&ved=0CE4Q6AEwBg#v=onepage&q=Osterby%20Man&f=false p. 112].</ref> The knot appears in several Roman depictions and on at least one other bog body, [[Dätgen Man]] (who wore his on the back of his head).<ref>Van der Sanden, ''Through Nature to Eternity'', p. 145; diagram of how it was tied, Ill. 202, p. 146.</ref> Osterby has featured the Suebian knot on its coat of arms since 1998.<ref>[http://www.schleswig-holstein.de/LA/DE/06Wappenlandschaft/0604Wappenrolle/0604Wappenrolle_node.html?Aktion=Datenblatt&ID=38 Gemeinde Osterby, Kreis Rendsburg-Eckernförde] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20131108235005/http://www.schleswig-holstein.de/LA/DE/06Wappenlandschaft/0604Wappenrolle/0604Wappenrolle_node.html?Aktion=Datenblatt&ID=38 |date=2013-11-08 }}, Kommunale Wappenrolle, State of Schleswig-Holstein State Archives {{de icon}}, retrieved 5 November 2013.</ref>
===Skin cape=== The skull was wrapped in fragments of a garment, measuring approximately {{convert|40|by|53|cm|in}}, consisting of [[Tanning (leather)|tanned]] pieces of leather sewn together. Microscopic analysis suggested on the basis of the hairs that they were from [[roe deer]]. The neck opening was lined with a strip of leather about {{convert|1|cm|in}} wide. All seams had been sewn with small stitches in [[catgut]]. Some appeared to be repairs. Textile archaeologists identified the garment as a skin cape; similar cloaks or capes have been found with other archaeological finds, including [[Elling Woman]], [[Haraldskær Woman]], [[Dröbnitz Girl]], [[Kayhausen Boy]] and [[Jührdenerfeld Man]].
===Treatment=== Peter Löhr performed the anthropological analysis, which determined that the skull had shrunk while immersed in the bog. For his doctoral dissertation, he performed experiments on it involving repeated soaking and drying and detailed measurements; in his view, soaking caused it to swell to almost its original dimensions.<ref>Peter Löhr, "Die Moorleiche von Osterby. Die experimentelle Schrumpfung von Schädeln", Anthropologisches Institut der Universität Kiel, 1950 (PhD dissertation) {{de icon}}</ref> Löhr's data included markedly shrunk teeth and the complete lower jaw associated with the skull, which has a protruding chin. However, more recent analysis has shown that in his original preparation of the skull for exhibition, [[Karl Schlabow]] added an unrelated lower jaw.<ref>Thomas Brock, [http://www.spiegel.de/wissenschaft/mensch/windeby-geheimnis-der-moorleichen-gelueftet-a-466195.html "Windeby: Geheimnis der Moorleichen gelüftet"], ''[[Der Spiegel]]'', 17 February 2007 {{de icon}}</ref>
===Dating=== The Suebian knot indicates the man died in the Late [[Iron Age]] or the Roman period, and [[radiocarbon dating]] likewise indicates a date between 75 and 130 [[Common Era|CE]];<ref>Van der Sanden, ''Through Nature to Eternity'', p. 81.</ref><ref>Johannes van der Plicht, Wijnand van der Sanden, A. T. Aerts and H. J. Streurman, [http://cio.eldoc.ub.rug.nl/FILES/root/2004/JArchaeolScivdPlicht/2004JArchaeolScivdPlicht.pdf "Dating bog bodies by means of 14C-AMS"] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20110917083915/http://cio.eldoc.ub.rug.nl/FILES/root/2004/JArchaeolScivdPlicht/2004JArchaeolScivdPlicht.pdf |date=2011-09-17 }}, ''Journal of Archaeological Science'' 31.4, 2004, pp. 471–91, p. 480.</ref> however, the hair sample used was taken from [[Alfred Dieck]]'s private collection and may thus be unreliable.<ref>Wijnand van der Sanden, "C14-Datierungen von Moorleichen aus Niedersachsen und Schleswig-Holstein", ''Die Kunde'' N.F. 46 (1995), 137–55 {{de icon}}</ref>
==Interpretation== Other Iron Age bog bodies have also been beheaded;<ref name=Eternity159/> the body of Dätgen Man, who also had a Suebian knot, was found several metres from his head. The beheading together with the fractured skull indicates deliberate execution by multiple methods. It is impossible to determine whether Osterby Man was sunk in the bog as a judicial punishment or a sacrifice, or whether his body was also deposited in the bog; but it has been suggested that his relatively advanced age may indicate an honorable death.<ref>''Proceedings of the Prehistoric Society'' 69–70 (2003) [https://books.google.com/books?ei=X6R5UvaEEMegjALVjoHgBA&id=epCBAAAAMAAJ&dq=Osterby+Man&focus=searchwithinvolume&q=+In+view+of+his+age%2C+he+may+have+been+an+elder+or+even+a+religious+leader p. 302].</ref>
==See also== *[[Stidsholt Woman]]
== References == {{reflist|30em}}

Neumünster: Wachholtz, 2002, {{ISBN|3-529-01870-8}} {{de icon}} *[[Karl Schlabow]]. "Haartracht und Pelzschulterkragen der Moorleiche von Osterby". ''Offa'' 8 (1949) 3–7 {{de icon}}
